Centrifugal force is not fake! It is such a disservice to say that for anyone who continues studying physics. A building that tall would disrupt the natural potential gradient that is necessary for this earth.  You would shift the current charge system, impacting the natural flow of charge from the ionosphere to the ground, and wreak havoc on weather phenomena and voltage profiles.  In short, that building would be lit up with St. Elmo's fire, and would likely partially disintegrate if not constructed with highly insulating material, assuming you could even begin to overcome the structural challenges.  It's a great thought experiment, however.

Actually Centrifugal force is the inward acting resistance to Centripetal Force (which she was indicating radially outward), which is the outward acting portion of the Radial Acceleration vector (Tangent to circular rotation).

A lot of material is needed to build the tower, so the mass and size of the Earth will decrease. We probably need the entire mass of the Earth. So the tower itself will become a satellite orbiting the sun.

Assuming the Earth could maintain the same rotation speed and remain balanced, the pressure on this space elevator cable would grow so much that it would snap way before reaching the length needed.

The electric force is not strong enough to allow anything to approach the speed of light. Imagine tiny vibration at the tip of this rope which travel in space at such speed. The atoms which got stretched by vibration would need to reconnect with the electric/magnetic lines that make them stick to each other. But the vibration is going faster than the speed of light, so the magnetic lines escape in spiral loops, similar to the solar wind. Those atoms would never regroup and would just fly away in empty space.

i have a serious question. Even if we build such a building hypothetically, we are still ignoring many things, such as:
1) the mass of the building will be too big due to its size, but it would be build from the mass on earth, so the mass distribution of the system changes drastically, due to which moment of inertia of the system changes too thus due to conservation of angular momentum, shouldn't the angular velocity decrease? and due to the decrease, the expected height of the building would be much lower than the original height of the building.
2) Due to change in mass distribution the centre of mass will also change, due to which we can't write the equation GM/r^2=(angular velocity)^2.r, as the r in this case will be different on both sides.

Dropping a satellite (or penny) at other heights can be useful for getting other orbits if you don't specify a circular orbit. If you released the penny at an altitude of 23555km it would orbit with its closest approach to Earth above the Kármán line, 100km above the Earth. Also you could release that penny at an altitude as high as 46848km and have it stay in orbit (ignoring influences from other bodies). Release it higher than that and you can launch it into interplanetary space for free. Release it from 144000km and you can go to Jupiter direct.

Dianna,

I'm trying to better understand gravitational time dilation (GTD) and I could use some help. I can only find subatomic test results, e. g. radioactive decay/muons, but I can not find test results at a higher level, by measure of testing the behavior of chemical elements. For example, let there be an atomic clock measuring time, down to the nanosecond, paired along with a closed system aquarium growing a crystal from a mass of chemical gas measured to exact atomic weight, down to the atom. Employing your "space-scraper" as an imaginary model to test a speculative hypothesis, if two similar aquariums and atomic clocks where placed in the building, one pair set in place at the top floor, and the other set at the bottom, when comparing the weights of the two grown crystals, after many years, between the two aquariums, would the top crystal weight more, be heavier in mass? I assume the top crystal would weigh more if the time dilation effect observed in the atomic clock is demonstrative of physical/chemical properties. I would be interested to see test results from non-subatomic clock experiments, as well as electrical tests, to affirm time dilation. Are there are any such alternative tests to read about the GTD subject?

My imagination is "seeing" a possible issue, but I don't know how to communicate it, other than with a not so great pseudo "science" experiment based upon a silly example: let there be a room with two clocks measuring time, one clock with a "pendulum" based from liquid water, and the other clock using a mechanical spring as its "pendulum." When the room temperature is lowered below freezing the water clock slows to a stop, and when the temperature is heated above boiling, the water clock dramatically speeds up, all the while the clock with a mechanical spring ticks along at, more or less, a consistent rate of speed. In other words, I wonder if the concentration of gravity alters atomic decay in an observable manner, but does this gravitational effect also equally change the rate of chemical reactions and vapor kinetics for non-radioactive elements, or electricity?

Cheers, Jeremy

The number she uses, 9.8m/s^2 is the gravitational acceleration at the earth's surface, actually Gme/Re^2, and it falls off with distance from the earth's surface, so her use of 9.8m/s^2 at some far distance, say at geosynchronous orbit (which is the about 35,000km altitude) isn't the force of the earth's gravity there. The dismissal of the Coriolis force in this lecture because you can't feel it is misleading since it effects everything from ocean currents, atmospheric weather patterns to even the deflection of cannons shot over distances of miles (and of course it is directional). Most of these youtube videos have been fairly interesting and relatively accurate, but this one is very misleading.

Fun fact! When I said you could find a place to settle down in earth’s molten core, it wouldn’t be in the plane of earth’s equator, because earth’s core is not entirely molten. It has two parts, a SOLID iron/nickel inner core with a radius of about 1,220 km, and a molten outer core that’s about 2,300 km thick. If you wanted rotate around at 100mph (161kph) on earth’s equatorial plane, you’d have to be 612km from the center of the earth which would put you in the solid core.

Sorry but I don't like the centrifugal force notion. There is only one force acting in the system and that is gravity. The penny is simultaneously moving laterally with constant velocity, and accelerating down towards the Earth. It never gets closer to the Earth though because its lateral motion ensures that the curving of the Earth's surface away from it, exactly matches the distance through which it falls. This is a hard thing to put into words and others have done it better. Sketches help too.

There's talk on here of centripetal forces, but that doesn't help really since they only have meaning with circular motion, and as we know orbits under gravity can be elliptical or even hyperbolic. So I think notions of circularity in these discussions don't help. Cometary orbits for instance can be highly elliptical, so much so that when they are far out in the solar system such comets may actually look as though they are falling towards the sun. The key word is "falling". This is really what the penny is doing even though its motion is actually circular.

This is interesting now. One guy below was talking about centrifuges. Imagine you're standing in a cradle that some giant is swinging around on a rope. Just like standing on the Earth you feel a floor beneath your feet and it feels like there's a force pulling you "down" (or outwards if you prefer) to that floor. This is why the notion of centrifugal force is so popular - because we've all experienced it. So why in the ISS aren't the astronauts thrown against the further wall of their space station? In both cases there is only one force acting, the rope wielded by the giant, or gravity in the ISS. And yet the astronauts drift weightlessly whilst you in your cradle are anything but. The difference between these two situations is as follows. The centripetal force applied to you by the rope is applied via the cradle floor. As you go up through your body, slice by slice, each slice applies and reacts the forces to the slices above and below, just like standing on the Earth. So it's like a pile of books on a table. The uppermost book only feels itself whereas the lowermost has to carry the force of all of them to the table. On the ISS however, the force of gravity isn't applied to an astronaut locally, through a floor or wall. It is applied to each and every atom and elementary particle of his body simultaneously.. So there is no stacking, slice upon slice. Every slice experiences the exact same force as every other. It's as though, instead of a single solitary rope, gravity has a vast number of ropes all pulling with the same acceleration on every particle of the astronaut's body, simultaneously.

People are very keen on the idea of a 'space elevator' - which would be taller than that and have a weight at the end to keep the 'cable' taught... There are several problems with that idea. First, you'd need a material with quite a bit more tensile strength than any we have now, and second, you'd need to pretty dramatically reduce the amount of space-junk... You can change the orbit of the ISS slightly. It's a bit hard to change the orbit of a skyscraper...

Orbiting isn't zero gravity, it is a sort of perpetual falling. When falling, everything is in the same place until some energy is added and things drift apart. The building would have to be as high as the the geostationary point which is quite high. Orbiting isn't really centrifugal force, just a vector change due to gravity so the track never goes back to Earth.... There are actually very few places in the Universe with zero gravity, but you can get close. Actually just thinking about it and there may be a centrifugal force, but it may not be significant until pretty far out. Maybe beyond the geostationary point, because objects are in collapse until then, if moving with the Earth's rotation.

One part of me says that to build this high, you need a material where the speed of sound is more than the orbital velocity because otherwise different levels will want to take different orbits and there'll be no time for lower levels to let the higher levels know that they're the same structure. The other part argues that neighboring levels already move with similar speeds, so their speeds relative to each other won't be that high. The first part speaks up again and says that the information will still ultimately have to be transferred from the very foundation to the very top, and they move with very different speeds. The second part says it doesn't because the material of top levels has gained its speed as you took it to the top while building the tower and now lies comfortably in its orbit that has to be only slightly adjusted by forces that hold solids together.
I wonder which one is right?
